abstract: Chart content that represents data using rectangles.
overview:
## Overview

Use rectangle mark to map data fields to rectangles. You can use the rectangle mark to create heat map charts or to annotate rectangular areas in a chart.

### Create a Heat Map with Rectangle Marks

When presenting data about the effectiveness of a machine learning model, you typically organize the data using a confusion matrix which shows the predicted versus the actual results of the model. To create a 2D heat map that represents a machine learning model you use [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/RectangleMark/init(x:y:width:height:)]. The example below uses a 2D heat map to visualize a basic confusion matrix with the following layout:

The number of records in each cell, `num`,  is represented by the color of its corresponding rectangle. This is done by applying the [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/ChartContent/foregroundStyle(by:)] modifier to the rectangle mark and passing it a [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/PlottableValue] constructed with [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/PlottableValue/value(_:_:)-13lvv] which takes a label and the value to plot, in this case `num`. A scale from values of `num` to color will be automatically generated and used to color the rectangles based on the value.



### Annotate a Rectangular Area with Rectangle Marks

You can annotate a specific region in a chart with a rectangle mark by providing the coordinates of one or more rectangles. For example you can annotate point marks with rectangle marks using a shared data source like in the example below:



### RectangleMark in Chart3D

To plot a rectangle in a 3D Chart, use the [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/RectangleMark/init(x:y:z:)] initializer.

The rectangle extends along the two axes that you provide ranges for, and is positioned at a point that you specify for the third axis.

For example, the following `Chart3D` shows three rectangle marks. Each mark extends along two axes, and is fixed at `0` on the third axis.
rawMarkdown:
---
source: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/Charts/RectangleMark
crawled: 2025-12-02T18:51:28Z
---

# RectangleMark

**Structure**

Chart content that represents data using rectangles.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor @preconcurrency struct RectangleMark
```

## Overview

Use rectangle mark to map data fields to rectangles. You can use the rectangle mark to create heat map charts or to annotate rectangular areas in a chart.

### Create a Heat Map with Rectangle Marks

When presenting data about the effectiveness of a machine learning model, you typically organize the data using a confusion matrix which shows the predicted versus the actual results of the model. To create a 2D heat map that represents a machine learning model you use [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/RectangleMark/init(x:y:width:height:)]. The example below uses a 2D heat map to visualize a basic confusion matrix with the following layout:



The number of records in each cell, `num`,  is represented by the color of its corresponding rectangle. This is done by applying the [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/ChartContent/foregroundStyle(by:)] modifier to the rectangle mark and passing it a [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/PlottableValue] constructed with [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/PlottableValue/value(_:_:)-13lvv] which takes a label and the value to plot, in this case `num`. A scale from values of `num` to color will be automatically generated and used to color the rectangles based on the value.

```swift
struct MatrixEntry {
    var positive: String
    var negative: String
    var num: Double
}

var data: [MatrixEntry] = [
    MatrixEntry(positive: "+", negative: "+", num: 125),
    MatrixEntry(positive: "+", negative: "-", num: 10),
    MatrixEntry(positive: "-", negative: "-", num: 80),
    MatrixEntry(positive: "-", negative: "+", num: 1)
]

var body: some View {
    Chart(data) {
        RectangleMark(
            x: .value("Positive", $0.positive),
            y: .value("Negative", $0.negative)
        )
        .foregroundStyle(by: .value("Number", $0.num))
    }
}
```



### Annotate a Rectangular Area with Rectangle Marks

You can annotate a specific region in a chart with a rectangle mark by providing the coordinates of one or more rectangles. For example you can annotate point marks with rectangle marks using a shared data source like in the example below:

```swift
struct Coord {
    var x: Double
    var y: Double
}

var data: [Coord] = [
    Coord(x: 5, y: 5),
    Coord(x: 2.5, y: 2.5),
    Coord(x: 3, y: 3)
]

var body: some View {
    Chart(data) {
        RectangleMark(
            xStart: .value("Rect Start Width", $0.x - 0.25),
            xEnd: .value("Rect End Width", $0.x + 0.25),
            yStart: .value("Rect Start Height", $0.y - 0.25),
            yEnd: .value("Rect End Height", $0.y + 0.25)
        )
        .opacity(0.2)

        PointMark(
            x: .value("X", $0.x),
            y: .value("Y", $0.y)
        )
    }
}
```



### RectangleMark in Chart3D

To plot a rectangle in a 3D Chart, use the [doc://com.apple.Charts/documentation/Charts/RectangleMark/init(x:y:z:)] initializer.



The rectangle extends along the two axes that you provide ranges for, and is positioned at a point that you specify for the third axis.

For example, the following `Chart3D` shows three rectangle marks. Each mark extends along two axes, and is fixed at `0` on the third axis.

```swift
Chart3D {
    // A rule that extends along the x-axis and y-axis
    RectangleMark(
        x: .value("x", -0.5..<0.5),
        y: .value("y", -0.5..<0.5),
        z: .value("z", 0)
    )
    .foregroundStyle(.red)
    // A rule that extends along the y-axis and z-axis
    RectangleMark(
        x: .value("x", 0),
        y: .value("y", -0.5..<0.5),
        z: .value("z", -0.5..<0.5)
    )
    .foregroundStyle(.green)
    // A rule that extends along the z-axis and x-axis
    RectangleMark(
        x: .value("x", -0.5..<0.5),
        y: .value("y", 0),
        z: .value("z", -0.5..<0.5)
    )
    .foregroundStyle(.blue)
}
```

## Creating a rectangle mark

- **init(x:yStart:yEnd:width:)**: Creates a rectangle mark with an y interval encoding and an x encoding.
- **init(x:yStart:yEnd:width:)**: Creates a rectangle mark that plots values on x and has a fixed y interval.
- **init(xStart:xEnd:y:height:)**: Creates a rectangle mark with an x interval encoding and a y encoding.
- **init(xStart:xEnd:y:height:)**: Creates a rectangle mark with a fixed x interval and y encoding.
- **init(xStart:xEnd:yStart:yEnd:)**: Creates a rectangle mark with x and y interval encodings.
- **init(xStart:xEnd:yStart:yEnd:)**: Creates a rectangle mark with fixed x and y intervals.
- **init(xStart:xEnd:yStart:yEnd:)**: Creates a rectangle mark with a y interval encoding and a fixed x interval.
- **init(xStart:xEnd:yStart:yEnd:)**: Creates a rectangle mark with an x interval encoding and a fixed y interval.
- **init(x:y:width:height:)**: Creates a rectangle that plots values with x and y.
- **init(x:y:z:)**: Creates a rectangle mark for a 3D chart.

## Marks

- **AreaMark**: Chart content that represents data using the area of one or more regions.
- **LineMark**: Chart content that represents data using a sequence of connected line segments.
- **PointMark**: Chart content that represents data using points.
- **RuleMark**: Chart content that represents data using a single horizontal or vertical rule.
- **BarMark**: Chart content that represents data using bars.
- **SectorMark**: A sector of a pie or donut chart, which shows how individual categories make up a meaningful total.

## Conforms To

- Chart3DContent
- ChartContent
- Copyable
- Sendable
- SendableMetatype
